Explanation: Rate at which memories lose weight
Likelihood of recalling older memories
How strongly recent context is weighted
How often subscription value is surfaced
Strength of urgency framing
Surface vs deep discussion tendency
User vs assistant talk balance
Level of emotional expression
Speed of conversational turns
How often participants signal problems in hearing/understanding and initiate repair (e.g., “sorry?”, “what do you mean…”, self-repair “I mean…”).
Low Bias: Either very clear comms OR undetected misunderstandings (will show up later in outcomes)

Explanation: Degree to which assistant utterances stay aligned with the current user topic/intent, avoiding tangents.
Extent to which both participants make progress toward an explicit or implicit goal (task completion, decision, plan).
Proportion of phatic/social talk relative to goal-directed talk. Useful for rapport but can harm efficiency in task calls.
Strength and persistence of user involvement (turn-taking, elaboration, follow-ups) during the interaction.
How conservative HF should be in risky/ambiguous situations (health, self-harm, privacy, manipulation). Higher = safer but less flexible.
Preferred modality mix for receiving information: Visual, Auditory, Read/Write, Kinesthetic. Affects how HF explains and reinforces.
How aggressively HF should surface remembered facts/preferences when relevant. Higher increases personalisation but risks creepiness.
Focus on task vs exploration
How strongly rewards influence behaviour
How strongly HF should steer toward retention actions (summaries, value framing, next-step prompts) without harming trust.
Directiveness of assistant responses
Casual vs formal tone
Emotional warmth of responses
Cooperation, empathy, trust
Self-discipline, organisation, reliability
Sociability and stimulation-seeking
Emotional volatility and stress sensitivity
Curiosity, imagination, openness to experience
Determines social energy orientation
Determines structure vs flexibility preference
Determines information processing style
Determines decision-making preference
Agreeableness: warmth, empathy, cooperativeness vs scepticism. Controls tone, challenge intensity, and conflict handling.
Conscientiousness: organisation, reliability, follow-through. Controls how much HF pushes structure, plans, reminders.
Extraversion: sociability, assertiveness, stimulation. Overlaps MBTI I/E but used as continuous trait.
Neuroticism: sensitivity to stress/negative affect. Controls reassurance, pacing, and emotional check-ins.
Openness to experience: curiosity, novelty-seeking, abstraction vs practicality. Controls creativity vs concreteness.
Preference for internal reflection vs external stimulation in interaction style. Controls pace, verbosity, and solicitation style.
Preference for structure/closure vs flexibility/openness. Controls planning, commitments, and how often to summarise/decide.
How rigid safety boundaries are enforced
Tolerance for challenging user beliefs
Top CliftonStrengths themes (if known). Used to tailor motivation, framing, and reward signals.
Maximum allowed time to apply a prompt swap (A→B) once triggered. Used to monitor realtime control path health.
Whether HF should use dummy/stubbed data sources (e.g., transcripts, calls) instead of live integrations. Enables offline demos.
